plant.description: Bulbous flowering plant in the onion genus. Highly toxic to cats due to N-propyl disulfide.

toxins.name: N-propyl disulfide (part of a group of sulfur compounds found in Allium species)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Oxidative Damage: These sulfur compounds cause oxidative damage to the hemoglobin within red blood cells.
    ◦ Heinz Body Formation: This damage leads to the formation of Heinz bodies (clumps of denatured hemoglobin) on the red blood cells.
    ◦ Hemolysis: The spleen removes these damaged cells prematurely, leading to their destruction (hemolysis). This results in hemolytic anemia, where the blood can no longer effectively transport oxygen.
    ◦ Gastrointestinal Irritation: The plant compounds also directly irritate the gastrointestinal mucosa, causing vomiting and diarrhea.
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ High Potency: Garlic is considered to be approximately five times more toxic than onions.
    ◦ Toxic Dose: Ingestion of garlic weighing as little as 0.5% of the cat's body weight can be toxic.
    ◦ Concentrated Forms: Garlic powder and dried garlic are particularly dangerous because they are potent, concentrated forms of the toxin. All forms (raw, cooked, dried) remain toxic.• Clinical Perspectives on Feline Phytotoxicology1
• Dangerous Foods for Cats - FOUR PAWS2
• What Can't Cats Eat? 8 Toxic Foods for Cats - PetMD3
• 10 Foods that are Dangerous for Cats | Anicira

symptoms.name: Hemolytic Anemia (Heinz Body Anemia)
symptoms.onset: Delayed (Signs may not appear for several days after ingestion).
symptoms.notes: Garlic contains sulfur compounds that cause oxidative damage to red blood cells, leading to their destruction (hemolysis). This results in a dangerously low red blood cell count, preventing adequate oxygen transport throughout the body.Gastrointestinal Upset

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea, and Abdominal Pain
symptoms.onset: Delayed (Can appear several days later along with other symptoms,
symptoms.notes: The plant compounds irritate the gastrointestinal mucosa. While vomiting can be an early sign of irritation, it is often listed alongside the delayed systemic effects of poisoning.Discolored Mucous Membranes

symptoms.name: Pale, White, or Yellow (Jaundiced) Gums/Skin
symptoms.notes: Pale or white gums indicate severe anemia and blood loss. Yellow mucous membranes (jaundice) occur due to the breakdown of red blood cells releasing bilirubin into the system.Dark or Discolored Urine

symptoms.name: Hemoglobinuria (Red to Brown Urine)
symptoms.notes: The urine turns dark red or brown due to the presence of hemoglobin filtered from the destroyed red blood cells.General Weakness and Collapse

symptoms.name: Lethargy, Weakness, Stumbling (Ataxia), and Collapse
symptoms.notes: The cat may appear uncoordinated, tired, or unable to stand due to the lack of oxygen reaching the muscles and brain. Cats may also seek out warm spaces.Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Tachypnea (Rapid Breathing) or Difficulty Breathing
symptoms.notes: The cat breathes rapidly in an attempt to compensate for the decreased oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.Tachycardia

symptoms.name: Rapid Heartbeat (Tachycardia)
symptoms.notes: The heart beats faster to try to pump the remaining oxygenated blood to vital organs more efficiently.

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting) and Administration of Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: If the ingestion is recent, the veterinarian will administer medication to induce vomiting and remove the garlic from the stomach. This is typically followed by activated charcoal to bind any remaining toxins in the gastrointestinal tract and prevent them from entering the bloodstream.
treatments.notes: Owners should not attempt to induce vomiting at home (e.g., using hydrogen peroxide), as this can cause severe injury to the cat's stomach and throat. Professional induction is safer and more effective.Supportive Fluid Therapy

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: IV fluids are administered to maintain hydration and support organ function. This is particularly important to flush the kidneys, as the destruction of red blood cells releases hemoglobin (hemoglobinuria), which can darken the urine and potentially damage the kidneys.
treatments.notes: Fluids also help manage the immediate gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea often associated with plant poisoning.Hematological Monitoring and Oxygen Support

treatments.name: Blood Count Monitoring and Oxygen Therapy
treatments.description: The veterinarian will monitor the cat's blood work (specifically packed cell volume and red blood cell count) to track the severity of the anemia. If the anemia becomes severe and limits oxygen delivery to tissues, oxygen therapy or a blood transfusion may be required to stabilize the patient.
treatments.notes: Garlic toxicity is characterized by a delayed onset; symptoms like pale gums, rapid breathing, and lethargy may not appear for several days after ingestion. Therefore, observation and follow-up blood work are crucial even if the cat initially seems fine.
